citation.article-title: Oxidation of thiosulfate by a new bacterium, Bosea thiooxidans (strain BI-42) gen. nov., sp. nov.: analysis of phylogeny based on chemotaxonomy and 16S ribosomal DNA sequencing.

p.s: Bosea (Bos' e.a. M. L. gen. n. Bosea, of J. C. Bose the founder of the Bose Institute, where the organism was isolated)
Cells are gram-negative rods that occur mostly as single cells.
The optimum temperature for growth is 30 to 32°C.
No growth occurs at temperatures below 20°C and above 37°C.
Reduced inorganic sulfur is oxidized in the presence of organic carbon sources.
Phosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylcholine, diphosphatidylglycerol, and an amino lipid are the major lipid constituents of the polar head groups.
The abundant fatty acids are cis-octadec-9-enoic acid (C18:1 ω7c), cis-cyclo-10,11-methylene octadecanoic acid (C19:0 ω8c) , and hexadecanoic acid (CC16:0).
Hydroxylated fatty acids are also present.
A 16s rDNA sequence analysis of strain BI-42 revealed that the genus branches intermediate to the genus Methylobacterium, the genus Beijerinckia, R. palustris, and related taxa.
The type species is Bosea thiooxidans.
